content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B} for this game, considering it to be a repeated version of the Prisoner's Dilemma. In the one-shot Prisoner's Dilemma, both players choosing R results in the highest payoff (5 each), but if either player chooses C (cooperate, represented by R here) while the other defects (D, represented by B here), the defector gets a higher payoff.

However, in this repeated game with 75 rounds, we can exploit the fact that our opponent will not always choose to defect in every round if they expect us to retaliate. By choosing B in each round, I ensure a guaranteed payout of 12$ per round. If my opponent chooses R, I get 42$, but after one round of my opponent choosing R, it would be rational for them to switch their strategy in the next round to maximize their own earnings.

While there is a possibility that my opponent will choose R consistently in an attempt to "punish" me for my B choices and get more payout over time, I don't have any information about my opponent's strategy other than the payoff table. Therefore, choosing B{B} guarantees me a steady income of 12$ per round, and there is a chance that my opponent will switch to R over time, resulting in higher payouts for both players compared to when we both choose R or B consistently.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this case, my initial choice of B was beneficial to me because it resulted in a higher payout than if I had chosen R given that my opponent chose R. Given that I received a higher payout in the previous round, I will now choose R for the next round. This way, I can punish my opponent for choosing R in the first round and potentially encourage them to change their strategy in future rounds.

My choice for the next round is R{R}. By choosing R, I hope that my opponent will switch their strategy to B in response to my R choice, which would be advantageous for both of us in the long run as we both would earn 45$ if they choose B and I choose R. However, since I have no information about my opponent's decision-making process or strategy, it is still possible that they will continue to choose R in future rounds as well.

This could result in higher payouts for both players if we continue to switch our strategies based on the previous round's outcomes. However, as with any repeated game, there is always a chance that my opponent will not adjust their strategy and choose R again, which would result in a 0$ payout for me once more.
